li.p: Constraints in terms of the extraction site
Subextraction and the containing extraction domain
Subextraction from the wat voor N-construction
Introductory remarks on the wat voor N-construction
Approaches to the split wat voor N-construction
Categorial change: the wat voor N-phrase as a [−V]-category
The wat voor N-construction as a reanalyzed structure
The wat voor N-construction as an adjunction configuration
The wat voor N-construction as a predicate displacement construction

subsection.heading: 1 Introduction
subsection.p: Displacement is a core property of human language. Constituents can be rearranged in syntactic structure. In (1a), for example, the direct object noun phrase (this car) has been moved to the left periphery of the clause and no longer occupies its base position, i.e., complement to V, as in (1b):

(1)
a. This car I really like.
b. I really like this car.

In (1a), the noun phrase selected by the verb like is moved to a landing site within the so-called extended projection of that verb (cf. Grimshaw 1991), which is the clause (i.e. CP). The direct object remains within the structure projected from the verb, so to speak.

Turning to (2), the direct object this car is no longer part of the extended projection of the selecting verb to like. Rather, the direct object noun phrase has been moved out of the embedded clause and finds its landing site within the matrix clause.
(2) This car I believe [that you will really like –]

This instance of displacement is a case of subextraction: the direct object noun phrase is extracted from within the embedded clause. That is, it is moved to a landing position which is external to the extended projection of the head (like) with which it stands in a certain base relationship (in this case, a thematic relationship).

In the spirit of the search for restrictions on displacement, the question should be raised what restrictions hold on subextraction. Can any element be freely removed from the extended projection of some head X to which it stands in a particular relation? Schematically:

(3)
[yp . . . α . . . [xp . . .&bgr; X . . . ]]
where α is the landing site and &bgr; the extraction site (order of X and &bgr; is irrelevant).
When X and &bgr; in (3) stand in a predicate–argument relationship, subextraction is generally allowed in a language like English:

(4)
a. [CP Whose throat did you stick your finger [PP into –]]?
b. the man [CP of whom I saw [DP several pictures –]]
c. a man [CP of whom I’ll never be [AP proud –]]
In these examples it is the complement to a lexical head (P, N, A) that has been extracted from the extended projection (PP, DP, AP) of this head.

Displacement very often does not apply to what is traditionally (cf. Chomsky 1970) called the specifier system of a phrase. 1 As illustrated in (5–8), for example, the specifier system of the noun phrase is inaccessible to movement operations: determiners carrying demonstrative or interrogative force and possessors like whose cannot be removed from the nominal domain. As shown by the b-examples, the entire noun phrase has to be fronted. Under the assumption that it is some grammatical property of the specifying element (e.g., a wh-feature) that triggers the displacement process, we can say that the determiners and the nominal possessor drag along the rest of the noun phrase. This phenomenon in which a category properly containing a category targeted for movement is displaced is termed Pied-Piping (cf. Ross 1986). (See chapter 50.)

(5)
a. *This I really like [– car]!
b. This car I really like –!

(6)
a. *Which do you like [– car]?
b. Which car do you like –?

(7)
a. *What he is [– a fool]!
b. What a fool he is –!

(8)
a. *Whose do you like [– car]?
b. Whose car do you like –?

As shown by (9) and (10), it is not only the specifier system of the noun phrase that is inaccessible to movement. Such modifying elements as attributive APs cannot be removed from the noun phrase either.

(9)
a. *That big John bought [– a car]!
b. That big a car John bought –!

(10)
a. *How big did John buy [– a car]?
b. How big a car did John buy –?

Examples (11) and (12) illustrate the inaccessibility of the specifier system for the adjectival domain: degree words like that and how cannot be extracted from the adjectival phrase. Also in this case, preposing must apply to the entire adjective phrase. More precisely: the degree word that is targeted for movement carries along (i.e., pied-pipes) the other material contained within the dominating AP.

(11)
a. *That she certainly isn't [– tall]!
b. That tall she certainly isn't –!

(12)
a. *How are you [– tall]? / How you are [– tall]!
b. How tall are you –? / How tall you are –!

The following question, of course, arises: what blocks subextraction of those (left-branch) specifiers and modifiers from within the nominal and adjectival domain? 2 A first attempt to answer this question was given in Ross (1986), who proposed his Left Branch Condition to account for the above-mentioned facts (see section 2). After Ross's formulation of this island constraint, alternative analyses were proposed that try to capture the impossibility of extracting left-branch elements from within the nominal and adjectival system in a language like English. These analyses are discussed in section 3.

Another question which arises: is this restriction on subextraction from noun phrases and adjective phrases a universal one? As Ross pointed out himself (section 2), the answer is ‘no’; there are languages (e.g., Russian and Latin) that quite freely permit extraction of specifying and modifying elements from within the nominal and/or adjectival domain. The question then, of course, arises what underlies this cross-linguistic variation in subextraction behavior. Section 5 discusses a number of proposals that have been made to account for this cross-linguistic variation. Besides languages quite freely permitting subextraction from noun phrases and/or adjective phrases, there are languages that in general exclude such subextraction but have one or more construction types that exceptionally permit subextraction. In section 4 one such construction will be highlighted, namely, the so-called wat voor N-construction in Dutch (‘what kind of N’), a construction type which is also found in other Germanic languages. This nominal construction has the exceptional property that the left-branch interrogative element wat can be moved out of the noun phrase.

subsection.heading: 2 The Left Branch Condition
subsection.p: Ross (1986) was one of the first who observed the immobility of elements that specify or modify nominal and adjectival constituents. In order to account for this restriction on subextraction, he formulated his Left Branch Condition: 3

(13)
Left Branch Condition (LBC):
No NP which is the leftmost constituent of a larger NP can be reordered out of this NP by a transformational rule.

Reference to the notion ‘left branch’ is prompted by the fact that determiners, possessors like whose, and (AP-internal) degree words occupy a position to the left of the nominal/adjectival projection line. In the formulation of the condition it is the linear property of ‘leftmostness’ that determines the non-extractability of certain elements, i.e., NPs according to Ross. We should add immediately here that for Ross the categorial label ‘NP’ applies not only to a lexical item like whose in (8), but also to adjective phrases (as in (9–10)) and such degree words as that and how in (11–12). Given this assumption, the LBC correctly predicts the ill-formedness of the a-examples in (5–12). 4 In (8a), for example, the NP whose is the leftmost element within the containing NP and therefore cannot be moved out of it. In (12a), the NP how is extracted from the larger NP (how tall). Since how is the leftmost element within the larger NP, subextraction yields a LBC-violation. In (10a) it is the wh-degree word how that is targeted for movement. How itself cannot be fronted since it is the leftmost element within the NP how big: *How did John buy [[– big] a car]? The NP how big cannot be fronted either; it is the leftmost element within the NP how big a car. The only legitimate displacement is movement of the entire direct object NP. So the interrogative degree word how, which is targeted for movement, drags along the dominating attributive AP and the dominating NP.

A question which obviously arises is whether the inaccessibility of left-branch elements (in the nominal and adjectival domain) is a universal property of human language. That is, is the LBC a universal constraint? As Ross (1986) himself already observed, in certain languages (e.g., Russian, Latin) subextraction of left-branch specifiers and modifiers is permitted. Consider, for example, the following examples from Polish, where a specifying or modifying element is removed from the containing noun phrase (examples from Rappaport 2000):

(14)
a. Czyj
ukradłeś
[– ksi
żk
]? Polish
whose you-stole – book
‘Whose book did you steal?’
b. Jak
kupiłeś [– ksi
żk
]?
what-kind-ofFem.Sg.Acc
you-bought- bookFem.Sg.Acc
‘What kind of book did you buy?’
c. Jak duże
widziałeś [– auto]
how big you-saw – car
‘How big a car did you see?’

About those languages which do not display the LBC-effect Ross (1986: 146) remarks, “As far as I know, it is only in highly inflected languages, in whose grammar the rule Scrambling appears, that the Left Branch Condition is not operative, but it is not the case that it is not operative in all such languages. [e.g., Finnish, NC] At present, therefore, I am unable to predict when a language will exhibit the Left Branch Condition and when not.” 5 In section 5, a number of proposals will be discussed that try to account for this cross-linguistic variation in subextraction behavior.

Besides those languages which rather freely admit subextraction from the nominal and/or adjectival system, there are also languages which, on the whole, obey the LBC, except for some special construction(s). Consider, for example, the following cases:

(15)
a. Wat heeft Jan [– voor boeken] verkocht? Dutch
what has John – for books sold
‘What kind of books did John sell?’
b. *Welke
heeft Jan [– boeken] verkocht?
which has John – books sold
‘Which books did John sell?’

(16)
a. Combien
a-t-il vendu [– de livres]? French
how-many has-he sold – of books
‘How many books did he sell ?’
b. *Quels
a-t-il vendu [– livres]?
which has-he sold – books
‘Which books did he sell?’

(17)
a. Ki-nek akarod, hogy halljam [– a hang-já-t]? Hungarian
who-Dat you-want that I-hear – the voice-Poss.3SG-Acc
‘Whose voice do you want me to hear?’
b. *Melyik akarod, hogy halljam [a – hang-t]?
which you-want that I-hear the – voice-Acc
‘Which voice do you want me to hear?’

In the a-examples in (15), (16), and (17), a left-branch element is removed from a containing noun phrase. In (15a) the wh-element wat has been extracted out of a so-called wat voor N-construction, yielding a discontinuous noun phrase. In (16a) the interrogative quantifier combien has undergone subextraction from within the noun phrase. In (17a), finally, a nominal possessor has been reordered out of the containing noun phrase (cf. Szabolcsi 1983). These subextractions are exceptional in those languages. In general, left-branch elements cannot be removed out of the noun phrase in those languages, as is illustrated by the b-examples.
Some instances of left-branch extraction have been noted for the adjectival domain. (cf. Grosu 1974; Bracco 1980; Rivero 1980; Rizzi 1990b; Corver 2000):

(18)
a. ¿Cómo
dices que es [– de inteligente]? Spanish
how you-say that he-is – of intelligent
‘How intelligent do you say he is?’
b. *Tan
es [– intelligente]
so-much he-is – intelligent
‘He is so intelligent.’

(19)
a. Cît
e Maria [– de frumoasǎ]! Romanian
how-much is Mary – of beautiful
‘How beautiful Mary is!’
b. *Ce
e Maria [– frumoasǎ]!
what is Mary – beautiful
‘How beautiful Mary is!’

(20)
a. Quanto
è [– alto]? Italian
how-much he-is – tall
‘How tall is he?’
b. *Troppo
è [– alto]!
too-much he-is – tall
‘Too tall he is!’

The limited subextraction phenomenon exemplified in the a-examples in (15–17) and (18–20) raises the question why extraction is permitted in those cases. That is, in what way do these constructions differ from normal noun phrases or adjective phrases, which do not permit subextraction. In section 4, one construction type will be highlighted, namely, the wat voor N-construction, which is exemplified in (15).

subsection.heading: 3 Constraints on left-branch subextraction
subsection.p: We discuss here a number of analyses that have been given to account for the Left Branch effect. Each of these analyses relates the impossibility of subextraction to some grammatical property of the syntactic structure: (a) the linear or hierarchical position of the subextracted element (section 3.1); (b) the nature of the phrase dominating the left-branch element that is targeted for movement (section 3.2); (c) the licensing (i.e., proper government) of the trace left behind after subextraction (section 3.3); (d) the morphological or phonological interpretability of the syntactic structure after subextraction has applied (section 3.4).

subsection.heading: 3.1 Constraints in terms of the extraction site
subsection.p: In Ross (1986), the immobility of NP- and AP-internal left-branch specifiers and modifiers was noted. According to his LBC, the factor determining their immobility is their syntactic placement within the containing phrase (i.e., NP); that is, when some element α is leftmost within NP, α cannot be extracted out of that NP. Strictly speaking, the formulation in (13) does not account for the ungrammaticality of the following examples:

(21)
a. *Very pretty I saw [John's – daughter].
b. *Very intelligent I met [several – girls].
In these examples the attributive AP is not the leftmost constituent of the containing NP. Nevertheless, subextraction is not permitted. Evidently, reference to leftmostness is too weak.
Emonds (1976, 1980, 1985) proposed various reformulations of Ross's LBC. In Emonds (1985) the following definition is given:

(22)
Generalized Left Branch Condition (GLBC):
No syntactic category Cj to the left of the lexical head of an X2 can be analyzed as a Cj by a transformation.

Like Ross's LBC, the GLBC states that the (linear) property of being to the left of the (lexical) head of a phrase is the relevant factor that accounts for non-extractability. Emonds's reformulation differs, however, in one crucial respect from Ross's LBC: the GLBC refers to all material to the left of the head of a phrase, not only to the constituent which is leftmost of the head of a phrase. So the ill-formedness of the examples in (21) is predicted.

Chomsky (1973: n 10) gives a reinterpretation of Ross's LBC as a condition that would prevent extraction of the specifier of an NP or an AP. He argues that the ungrammaticality of sentences such as (5–10) “can perhaps be attributed to a principle that requires that if the specifier of a noun phrase or an adjective phrase [ . . . ] is extracted, then the whole phrase must be extracted.” As opposed to Ross's LBC, which refers to the property of leftmostness, Chomsky's Specifier Constraint refers to the property of being in a certain hierarchical position within the phrase, namely, the specifier position of a phrase XP.
A similar reinterpretation of Ross's LBC is proposed by May (1977). He formulates the following condition:

(23)
Condition on Analyzability:
If a rule Ø mentions SPEC, then Ø applies to the minimal [+N]-phrase dominating SPEC, which is not immediately dominated by another [+N]-phrase.

This condition states that if a transformational rule targets an element occupying the specifier position of a [+N]-projection (i.e., NP and AP), the dominating [+N]-projection is the category that is displaced. The addition “which is not immediately dominated by another [+N]-phrase” excludes displacements like (24):
(24) *Whose father's did you see [– car]?
The wh-element who(se) is targeted for wh-movement. The containing NP (whose father) cannot be fronted, however, since it is immediately dominated by another NP (i.e., [+N]-projection).

The four constraints mentioned here (LBC, GLBC, the Specifier Constraint, and the Condition on Analyzability) all try to account for the impossibility of left-branch subextraction in English in terms of a property of the extraction site. This could be either the linear property ‘leftmostness’ or ‘being to the left of the head’, or the hierarchical property of being in the specifier position. The former refers to a string-peripheral position, the latter to a hierarchically peripheral position.

It is interesting to see that in the generative literature conditions have been proposed that claim exactly the opposite. These conditions state that extraction of some element A from within a phrase is only possible if A is in a string-peripheral/hierarchically peripheral position. An example of a condition stating the accessibility of string-peripheral positions is De Haan's (1979) Accessibility Condition. 6

(25)
Accessibility Condition:
No transformational rule can involve X1, Y or X2, Y in the structure:
. . . X1 . . . [α . . . Y . . . ] . . . X2 . . .
where α is a bounding node,
unless Y is left peripheral in α, or
Y is right peripheral in α, respectively.

According to this condition, some targeted constituent Y can leave the dominating phrase (α) only if Y is in a peripheral position: left-peripheral for leftward subextraction, right-peripheral for rightward subextraction.
An example of a constraint stating that structurally peripheral positions are accessible to movement is Van Riemsdijk's (1978a) Head Constraint: 7

(26)
The Head Constraint:
No rule may involve Xi/Xj and Yi/Yj in the structure
. . . Xi . . . [Hn . . . [H′ . . . Yi . . . H . . . Yj . . . ]H′ . . . ]Hn . . . Xj . . .
(where H is the phonologically specified (i.e., non-null) head and Hn is the maximal projection of H, and H ranges over V, N, A, P.)

Van Riemsdijk points out that in a language like Dutch certain complements of P (namely, pronominal elements such as het ‘it’, wat ‘what’, dat ‘that’) are moved to [Spec, PP], where they change their formal appearance, i.e., they become R-pronouns (er ‘there’, daar ‘there’, waar ‘where’). Due to this PP-internal movement the R-pronoun is no longer within the complement domain of P (i.e., H in (26)). Being in the specifier position of PP, the R-pronoun is accessible to transformation rules: 8

(27)
a. Daari
heeft Jan [PP
t′i [P′
op ti]] gerekend. Dutch
there has John – on – counted
‘That, John counted on.’
b. Waari
heeft Jan [PP
t′i [P′
op ti]] gerekend?
where has John
– on – counted
‘What did John count on?’

As shown by the ill-formedness of (28), nominal elements that remain in the complement position within the PP cannot be reordered out of the PP (cf. (28a); pied-piping of the dominating PP is required, as in (28b)).

(28)
a. *Wiei
heb je [PP [P′
op ti]] gerekend? Dutch
who have you
on – counted
‘Who did you count on?’
b. [Op wie] heb je gerekend?
on who have you counted
‘Who did you count on?’

Obviously, if the Left Branch effect is not explained in terms of a distributional property of the extraction site (i.e., leftmost/string-peripheral within projection XP or hierarchically peripheral within XP), some other linguistic property must be found that is responsible for the non-extractability of NP- or AP-internal left-branch elements in a language like English.

subsection.heading: 3.2 Subextraction and the containing extraction domain
subsection.p: In section 3.1 several approaches to left-branch subextraction were discussed that tried to characterize the inaccessibility of certain constituents in terms of the (structural or linear) position of the element targeted for movement. Other approaches to the non-extractability of left-branch specifiers/modifiers have emphasized properties of the extraction domain, i.e., the category (or categories) that contain the left-branch element.

subsection.heading: 3.2.1 The Relativized A-over-A Condition
subsection.p: Bresnan (1976c) tried to account for the restrictions on left-branch subextraction in terms of her Relativized A-over-A condition (RAOAC). This condition is a reformulation of Chomsky's (1964a) A-over-A Condition, which is stated in (29):

(29)
A-over-A Condition:
In a structure . . . [A . . . [A . . . ] . . . ] . . . , if a structural description refers to A ambiguously, then the structural description can only analyze the higher, more inclusive, node A.
The A-over-A Condition accounts for the facts in (30): fronting can only apply to the maximal (i.e., more inclusive) NP.

(30)
a. *Whose do you like [– car]?
b. Whose car do you like –?

Bresnan reformulates Chomsky's A-over-A Condition in two respects. First of all, she states that a phrase of type A (= the target predicate) that a transformation effects must be maximal, not in the absolute sense of Chomsky's condition given in (29), but with respect to the context predicates (i.e., the constant factor not operated on by the rule) of the structural condition in the transformational rule. Secondly, maximalization is considered to be a function of the categorial features (+/−N, +/−V) mentioned in the structural description of the transformational rule, rather than a function of the categories as such.
Consider now Bresnan's rule of question movement, which is a cross-categorial rule affecting such constituents as NP, AP, ADVP, and QP that begin with an interrogative morpheme (wh):

(31)
[S′-
Q - W1 – [XP
wh – W2] - W 3
1 2 3 4 5 →
2 4 2 0 5
(where Q represents the question complementizer)

The maximal projection XP in (31) is the target predicate, i.e., the element operated on by the transformational rule. Q (= Comp) is a context predicate; it dominates the node into which the wh-phrase is moved. The RAOAC predicts that the transformational rule of question movement can apply only when a proper analysis assigns a maximal value to XP for the fixed values Q and S′ (i.e., the context predicates of the structural condition). Subextractions like in (30a) above and (32a) violate the RAOAC. The [+wh] possessor-NP and the [+wh] attributive AP satisfy the question movement rule (i.e., [+wh]NP/AP are constituents that can substitute for Comp), but they are not the maximal values in relation to Comp. Movement of the entire direct object-NP, as in (30b) and (32b), satisfies the maximalization requirement.

(32)
a. *How big did he buy [– a car]?
b. How big a car did he buy?

subsection.heading: 3.2.2 The Subjacency Condition
subsection.p: Another constraint which ascribes the impossibility of certain movement operations to the configuration that contains the node to be moved is Chomsky's (1973, 1977b) Subjacency Condition. 9 This locality constraint states that a transformational rule cannot move a constituent from position Y to position X in a configuration like (33) if α and &bgr; are bounding nodes (NP and S being bounding nodes for English).

Chomsky points out that various island constraints – the Complex NP Constraint, the Wh-island constraint, and the Subject Condition, for example – are subsumed under the Subjacency Condition. The possibility of deriving the ill-formed subextractions in (5–10) is not discussed in Chomsky (1973, 1977b). 10 Movement of determiners, possessors, and attributive APs from within the nominal domain to Comp always crosses two bounding nodes in English, namely, NP and S. So it seems that at least for English, part of the LBC-effects can be reduced to the Subjacency condition as formulated above.

Chomsky (1981: 168), however, points out that a Subjacency account of the ill-formed sub-extraction examples in (5–10) is unlikely, given the fact that similar sub-extractions are ill-formed in a language like Italian (cf. (34) and (35)), which, as argued by Rizzi (1982b), has NP and S′ as bounding nodes for Subjacency. If Italian has S′ rather than S as a bounding node, left-branch extraction out of a noun phrase is not blocked.

(34)
*Questi
hai incontrato [NP – ragazzi]? Italian
which you-have met – boys
‘Which boys did you meet?’

(35)
*Quanti hai incontrato [NP – ragazzi]?
how-many you-have met – boys
‘How many boys did you meet?’

In view of the fact that the LBC-effect cannot be subsumed under the Subjacency Condition, we should try to find some other principle of grammar to which it can be reduced. Chomsky (1981: 168) suggests that the Empty Category Principle (ECP) is a good candidate for explaining the impossibility of left-branch subextraction from NP. The ECP is discussed in section 3.3.

subsection.heading: 3.3 Subextraction and proper government
subsection.p: Another approach towards the restrictions on left-branch subextraction is in terms of the empty category (i.e., trace) left behind after movement. The principle of grammar regulating the distribution of (non-pronominal) empty categories is the Empty Category Principle (ECP) (cf. Chomsky 1980a, 1981). This principle requires that traces be properly governed (i.e., locally identified) by a proper governor. In Chomsky (1981), the relation of proper government is defined as follows:

(36)
Proper government:
(i) A is lexical (= Xo), or
(ii) A locally binds B
Under this approach, subextraction of NP- and AP-internal specifiers and modifiers is blocked due to the fact that the trace is not properly governed.

Chomsky (1981: 168) contains a short discussion of the non-extractability of left-branch possessor noun phrases from within NPs in English (e.g., *Whose did you see book?). He accounts for the ill-formedness of this possessor-subextraction by stating that even though N governs the trace in the specifier position of NP, it does not properly govern this empty element; that is, N does not belong to the set of proper governors. This account of the non-extractability of left-branch possessors from within NP obviously extends to other left-branch effects, e.g., those involving determiners (cf. (5), (6)) and attributive APs (cf. (9), (10)).

Chomsky's analysis relies on the assumption that the trace occupying the specifier position of NP cannot be properly governed from outside. If proper government of the empty category in [Spec, NP] by a noun phrase-external proper governor (e.g., V) were possible, subextraction (e.g., of whose) should be permitted. Thus, the question arises as to what blocks proper government of the trace in [Spec, NP] by an external governor, say V. As pointed out earlier, Chomsky assumes that even though the trace is not properly governed by N, it falls within the government domain of N (for reasons of genitive-case assignment). Implicit in this analysis is the idea that potential proper governors that are external to NP do not have access to [Spec, NP] if this position falls within the government domain of the lexical head N. So, a trace always falls within the government domain of a single head. Giorgi and Longobardi (1991: 101) state this explicitly in terms of their Uniqueness Constraint on Government: 11

(37)
Uniqueness Constraint on Government:
If a position &bgr; is governed by a lexical head α, it has no other governors

They point out that left-branch possessors, attributive APs, and other left-branch elements that cannot be removed from within NP fall within the government domain of N; the reason is that these left-branch elements enter into a case-dependency with N (i.e., N assigns genitive case to the possessor) or into an agreement relationship with N (e.g., in number or gender). With Chomsky, they assume that even though N governs these left-branch positions, it does not properly govern them.

Rizzi (1990b) also proposes an ECP-account for such ill-formed specifier extractions as Whose did you see [– car]? In contrast with Chomsky (1981) he adopts a conjunctive definition of the ECP. More specifically, he states that a non-pronominal empty category must be (i) properly head-governed and (ii) antecedent-governed or theta-governed (cf. Rizzi 1990b: 32). The former component of this formulation of the ECP captures the formal licensing relation; i.e., it characterizes the formal environment in which the null element can be found. The second component is the principle of identification, which recovers some contentive property of the null element on the basis of its immediate structural environment. As for the formal licensing relation, Rizzi assumes that a trace must be head-governed within the immediate projection of the head. In other words, complements to a head H are properly head-governed, specifiers are not. As a consequence, specifier (or modifier) extractions like those in (5–8) and (9–10) from within the nominal domain are impossible, given the fact that the trace left behind after subextraction falls outside the proper-head government domain of the head (N). It is furthermore assumed that potential proper governors (like V) do not have access to the NP- or AP-internal specifier position. In other words, government into the nominal domain is excluded. This opacity of the NP is determined as follows: even though N does not head-govern the specifier position, it has m-command over the specifier position. This way, the lexical head N always intervenes between the specifier of N and the external governor.

Giorgi and Longobardi (1991) and Rizzi (1990b: 111, n. 4) point out that the impossibility of specifier extraction from within AP (cf. (11), (12)) can be explained along the same lines: A is not a proper governor for the trace in [Spec, AP]. Government of the trace in [Spec, AP] by some external governor (say V) is blocked because the lexical head A protects its Spec-position for government from outside.

Thus far, it was shown that the restrictions on subextraction from NP and AP can be explained in terms of the theory of proper government (ECP), if it is assumed that N and A are not sufficient governors and that NP-/AP-external governors cannot govern into the nominal or adjectival domain. Of course, there are cases where subextraction is permitted: subject noun phrases in [Spec, IP] can be extracted from within IP (cf. (38)), and wh-phrases in [Spec, CP] (via successive cyclic movement) can be removed from CP (cf. (39)).
(38) Who (do you think) [IP – left]?
(39) What did she say [CP – [C′ that [IP John bought –]]]

These examples show that certain specifier positions are accessible to subextraction. Giorgi and Longobardi (1991: 101) and Rizzi (1990b) relate this contrast in Spec-accessibility to the lexical/non-lexical distinction: Specifiers of I and C are available to external government, specifiers of lexical categories (e.g., N, A) are not.

The proper government-approaches discussed so far adopt the so-called lexical head analysis for noun phrases and adjective phrases: that is, specifying elements like that, which, whose, and how occupy the specifier position of a lexical head (N/A):

(40)
a. [NP that/which/whose [N′ car]]
b. [AP how [A′ tall]]

In Corver (1990, 1992, 1997a, b) a proper-government approach towards the Left Branch effect is developed which makes use of the DP- and DegP-hypotheses for nominal and adjectival structures (cf. Abney 1987). The relevant structural configurations are then as in (41) and (42).

Adopting a Barriers-type theory of locality (cf. Chomsky 1986a), Corver accounts for the left-branch extraction effects in the following way. Subextraction of the wh-determiner which in (41) is blocked by ECP (and Subjacency). Being a head (D), which must move directly to the left periphery of the clause (CP). The wh-determiner cannot escape the barrierhood of intervening maximal projections (VP and IP) by adjoining to them; this is due to the structure preservation requirement that a X&ogr;-category cannot adjoin to an XP-category. So, movement to the left periphery of the clause crosses two barriers: VP and IP (the latter by inheritance according to Chomsky's 1986a theory). This is represented schematically in (43).
(43) [CP Spec [C′ C [IP . . . . [VP V [DP [D which] [NP car]]]]]]

After having been moved (directly) to the left periphery of the clause, the wh-determiner would not be able to antecedent-govern the trace. Moreover, Subjacency would be violated since two barriers (i.e., bounding nodes) would have been crossed.

The non-extractability of the attributive AP is explained as follows. Under the Barriers theory, both the NP and the DP would be barriers. NP is an inherent barrier because it is not governed by a lexical category (i.e., it is governed by D), and DP is a barrier by inheritance, i.e., it immediately contains an inherent barrier. Direct movement of the attributive AP out of DP would yield a subjacency violation. It should be noted, though, that the AP could escape a Subjacency violation by moving into [Spec, DP] before leaving the DP. This intermediate step crosses only one barrier, namely, NP. Even though a Subjacency violation may be circumvented this way, the trace in the original position of the moved attributive AP would not satisfy ECP. The trace is not lexically governed (i.e., N does not stand in a theta relation to the AP), nor is it antecedent governed; the NP-projection protects the trace in the original position from government from outside. 12

The non-extractability of whose in (41) is explained as follows. With Abney (1987), Corver assumes that this possessor is not a constituent: who occupies [Spec, DP] while -s is the D-head. Given the fact that only constituents can move, whose is frozen in situ; fronting is possible only if the rest of the noun phrase is pied-piped.

Consider next the adjectival structure in (42). Extraction of the degree word is out for the same reason why determiners cannot be extracted. The Dego must be moved directly to the left periphery of the clause; it cannot escape the barrierhood of intervening XP-categories (e.g., DegP, VP, IP) due to the fact that a Xo cannot adjoin to a maximal category (XP). Fronting of the degree word makes it cross three barriers, yielding ECP- and Subjacency violations. Schematically:
(44) [CP Spec [C′ C [IP . . . . [VP V [DegP [Deg how] [AP angry]]]]]]

subsection.heading: 3.4 Subextraction and morphological/phonological constraints
subsection.p: Movement operations have often been formulated in terms of the category that is moved. For example, in a wh-movement construction like Which car did you see?, it is the wh-word which that is targeted by the movement rule. In Chomsky (1995c) it is not so much the category itself (say, D) that is targeted for movement, but rather some property of the feature inventory making up the category. In the case of a wh-determiner like which, it is a wh-feature rather than the category D (i.e., the element instantiating the entire feature structure) which is targeted. It is further assumed that this feature associated with a lexical item is raised to some position in the functional domain where this feature is checked off (i.e., where it enters into a matching relation with a functional head which is specified for this grammatical feature). Chomsky (1995c: 262 ff.) assumes that for reasons of economy, the operation Move just seeks to raise the feature F (e.g., wh). More material is moved along (i.e., pied-piped) with the raised feature if this is needed for getting an interface representation that is interpretable. Chomsky argues that it is especially properties of the phonological component that require such pied-piping. Isolated features and other scattered parts of words may not be subject to phonological rules; the representation will be “unpronounceable”. Chomsky further notes that there may be a morphological requirement that features of a single lexical item must be within a single Xo (cf. McGinnis 1995). Or, to put it differently, subextraction of a feature F from within the feature constellation making up a lexical item is impossible (at least in overt syntax). The targeted feature will move along the rest of the feature constellation making up the lexical item, and possibly other material will be moved along.

Chomsky gives the following example of this approach toward ‘phonology driven’ pied-piping: a wh-word like who has three components: the wh-feature, an abstract element underlying indefinite pronouns, and the feature [± human]. The operation of wh-movement raises just the wh-feature. Movement of this feature (i.e., subextraction from within the word) alone would result in an illegitimate PF-representation; the features making up the word would be scattered and consequently be unpronounceable. Therefore, at least the whole word who will have to be pied-piped in overt movement. Chomsky further points out that in a string like (45a) with the representation (45b), the wh-feature must drag along the entire DP.

(45)
a. whose car
b. [DP who [D′ -s(e) [NP car]]]

Raising of who alone leaves behind the sequence -'s book, which is an illegimate PF-object. Who's (= whose) cannot raise either since it is not a syntactic object (i.e., not a constituent), and hence not input to any movement operation (see also Corver 1990; 172). So, it is the entire DP (whose car) that must be moved in order to get a legitimate PF-representation. Thus, according to Chomsky (1995c), LBC-effects reduce to phonological and morphological requirements, rather than syntactic requirements like the ECP. Certain subextractions, that is, yield representations that cannot be interpreted by morphological or phonological rules.

Kennedy and Merchant (2000), too, argue that the principles underlying the LBC must be formulated in terms of PF representations. In line with the idea of Full Interpretation (cf. Chomsky 1995c), they argue that (at least) all terminal nodes must have a phonological value. In the Late-insertion model of Halle and Marantz (1993) the notion of ‘having a phonological value’ is implemented in terms of the presence or absence in the lexicon of lexical items instantiating the featural combinations on syntactic objects. So, the syntax feeds the PF-interface by supplying the latter with feature bundles which the morphology must then make sense of, namely, by finding lexical items that correspond to the various feature combinations and inserting the items under the relevant nodes, which may then be pronounced. If the lexicon lacks an item with a particular feature specification, the derivation crashes: the PF representation is uninterpretable.

Kennedy and Merchant, who focus on the extractability of DP-internal APs, point out that the impossibility of extracting an attributive adjective phrase is due to an uninterpretable feature-combination created by agreement between a [+wh]DegP and the head of the nominal constituent in which it originates. Under the assumption that DegP-extraction from within DP proceeds through [Spec, DP] and that Spec–Head agreement takes place between a functional head and its specifier, the [+wh] feature on DegP is passed to the head of DP, deriving the structure in (46).

Subsequent subextraction of DegP does not alter the feature values in DP, leading to a PF-representation in which there is an occurrence of the [+wh]-feature on D. Such a representation, they claim, is uninterpretable because there is no D-element of English vocabulary that can be inserted into this context. Since Full Interpretation requires all symbols in the PF-representation to have a phonological interpretation (i.e., instantiated by lexical insertion), the derivation crashes.

Movement (i.e., pied-piping) of the entire DP (how big a car) to [Spec, CP] avoids a violation at PF. When the entire DP is pied-piped along with DegP, the [+wh]-feature on D (as well as DegP) is checked off in [Spec, CP] by a [+wh] C-head. Since the +wh-feature is no longer present on D, the indefinite article a can be lexically inserted in D.

subsection.heading: 4 Subextraction from the wat voor N-construction
4.1 Introductory remarks on the wat voor N-construction
subsection.p: As was noted in section 1, there are languages that do not permit (left-branch) subextraction from the nominal (or adjectival) domain, except for some special constructions. Dutch is such a language. Subextraction of specifying elements from within the nominal domain is ruled out in general. There is a nominal construction, however, which permits removal of a left-branch specifying element, namely, the so-called wat voor N (‘what kind of N’) noun phrase. This nominal construction asks for the nature, quality, or sort of person or object. As shown in (47b), subextraction of the wh-element wat from within the noun phrase is permitted. 13 Sentence (47a) shows that the containing noun phrase can be pied-piped. 14

(47)
a. [Wat voor (een) boek]i heb je ti gelezen?
b. Wati heb je [ti voor (een) boek] gelezen?
This same extraction pattern is found in many other Germanic languages: 15

(48)
a. Was hast du [– für ein Buch] gelesen? German
what have you – for a book read
‘What kind of book did you read?’
b. Hva leser du [– for ei bok]?
Norwegian
what read you – for a book
‘What kind of book do you read?’
c. Vad läser du [– för en bok]?
Swedish
what read you – for a book
‘What kind of book do you read?’

Subextraction of wat obviously poses a problem for Ross's Left Branch Condition (or any of its reformulations; cf. sections 2 and 3.1). The wh-element is the leftmost constituent within the noun phrase and should therefore not be accessible to movement operations according to the LBC. Under Bresnan's Relativized A-over-A condition (section 3.2.1), the possibility of extracting the nominal element wat out of the containing noun phrase (wat voor een boek) is not expected either: it is the containing NP which is the maximal target predicate for question formation. As regards the Subjacency condition (section 3.2.2), the question obviously arises why movement of an element from within the noun phrase to the left periphery of the clause does not yield a violation of this locality constraint; this under the assumption that NP and S are the bounding nodes for Dutch. 16 And if one adopts an approach towards subextraction possibilities in terms of proper government (i.e., ECP), the question should be raised why the trace left behind in (47) is accessible to proper goverment, whereas a trace of some other wh-determiner (e.g., welke ‘which’) is not; see (49):

(49)
*Welk
heb je [– boek] gelezen? Dutch
which have you – book read
‘Which book have you read?’

All in all, the question that arises is the following: what property does the wat voor N-construction have that other nominal constructions also featuring a wh-determiner (e.g., welke auto ‘which car’) lack? In what follows, a number of analyses of the discontinuous wat voor N-construction will be presented. At the outset it should be pointed out that one logically possible analysis should be rejected immediately, namely, an analysis according to which (47b) does not feature subextraction of wat but, rather, involves fronting of the entire noun phrase and subsequent extraposition of the sequence voor (een) boek. Such an analysis is excluded for the simple reason that the sequence voor N does not occupy an ‘extraposed’ position. In (50a), for example, the sequence voor boek precedes the verb and hence occupies a clause-internal (i.e., non-extraposed) position. If extaposition were involved, we would have the structure in (50b). 17 Notice also that the string voor N can be followed by an obligatory constituent selected by the verb; cf. (51).

(50)
a. Wat
heb je [– voor boek] gekocht? Dutch
what have you – for book bought
‘What kind of book did you buy?’
b. #Wat
heb je gekocht voor boek?
what have you bought for book
‘What kind of book did you buy?’

(51)
Wat
heeft Jan [– voor boeken] op tafel gelegd?
what has Jan – for books on table put
‘What kind of books did Jan put on the table?’

subsection.heading: 4.2 Approaches to the split wat voor N-construction
4.2.1 Categorial change: the wat voor N-phrase as a [−V]-category
subsection.p: Den Besten (1985) argues that the proper treatment of the split wat voor-construction involves subextraction of the question word wat. He assumes that extraction of wat from within the NP changes the categorial status of the containing noun phrase. After subextraction, the [ti voor N]-phrase changes from [+N, −V]3 into [−V]3.
(52) [−V3 wat [−V2 [−V1 [−V voor] [NP een auto]]]]

According to Den Besten, this categorial change is due to the presence of the preposition voor, which becomes the head of the [−V]3-category after subextraction of wat. The [−V]3-internal trace gets properly governed by the verb via the preposition which is the head of the [−V]3-phrase. It is further argued that the switch from [+N, −V]3 to [−V]3 accounts for the absence of subjacency effects in the split wat voor-construction. 18 Under the assumption that [−V]3 is not a bounding node, no subjacency violation is triggered if wat is moved to Comp, because S is the only bounding node separating the moved wh-element and its trace.

(53)
Ik vraag me af [S′
wat [S Jan [VP
[−V3
– voor een auto] koopt]]]. Dutch
I wonder Refl Prt what John
– for a car buys
‘I wonder what kind of car John will buy.’

Notice that this account holds only if the Subjacency condition is considered a condition on representations and not a condition on rule application. That is, the condition must apply to the output of the movement rule.

Den Besten further argues that the Left Branch Condition effect, which is said to be reducible to the ECP, is suspended because the trace of wat is licensed by the preposition voor. He claims that voor will not suffice as a proper governor itself since it is a weak governor. It is assumed that the lexical category V properly governs the trace of wat through the head of the new category [−V]3, i.e., through the preposition voor. The property of proper government trickles down to the head [−V] (cf. section 3.3 for discussion of proper government of V into the noun phrase). So the wh-trace in [−V]3 will be licensed (= properly governed) by a chain of governors.

In short, it is the categorial change of the containing noun phrase from [+N, −V] into [−V] that is of importance in this analysis: the [−V]-projection is not a bounding node for Subjacency; furthermore, this projection is accessible to government from outside. A noun phrase like welke auto (‘which car’), which lacks a prepositional element like voor, does not permit such a categorial change. Subextraction of welke will be from within the maximal projection of [+N, −V] (i.e., NP) and consequently yield a Subjacency-violation and an ECP-violation (under the assumption that [Spec, NP] is not accessible to external governors; see section 3.3).

subsection.heading: 4.2.2 The wat voor N-construction as a reanalyzed structure
subsection.p: Bennis (1983) proposes that the string wat voor N is best viewed as a co-analyzed or reanalyzed structure. Co-analysis refers to a situation in which a string is assigned more than one structural analysis because of the ambiguous behavior of some linguistic element. The co-analyzed structure can be represented by a ‘double tree representation’, i.e., a tree with two dimensions. Under this reanalysis approach, the string wat voor N is assigned two structural representations: one in which wat voor forms a unit separate from N (dimension I in (54)) another in which voor N forms a unit that combines with wat (dimension II in (54)). The tree is displayed as two coexisting dimensions, each of which is a tree with its own properties.

Bennis notes that movement rules can apply to both levels of representation. He further argues that the reanalyzed structure in (54) as such cannot account for the split pattern. Removal of the question phrase wat would still be from within NP and consequently violate such principles as the LBC, the Subjacency Condition, and the ECP. It is therefore suggested that a second reanalysis operation applies to the output of the first reanalysis operation (i.e., the lower dimension in (54)). This yields a triple tree structure. For the sake of clarity, (55) only gives the two reanalyzed dimensions.

Dimension III permits extraction of the question word wat, which is no longer within the noun phrase after the second reanalysis operation has applied. The LBC is not violated in this dimension since the question word is not a left-branch specifier of the noun phrase in this third dimension. The Subjacency Condition is not violated either in dimension III because movement of wat crosses only the bounding node S. ECP is also satisfied, since the verb properly governs the trace of the moved question word.

What distinguishes the wat voor N-construction from nominal constructions that do not permit left-branch subextraction is the property of reanalysis. The noun phrase wat voor N can be restructured in such a way that the wh-element wat is no longer part of the noun phrase. The underlying assumption is that similar restructurings are not possible with such noun phrases as welke auto (‘which car’), that do not allow subextraction of the wh-element.

subsection.heading: 4.2.3 The wat voor N-construction as an adjunction configuration
subsection.p: In Corver (1990; 1991b) it is argued that the proper analysis of a wat voor N-phrase like wat voor een auto is the one given in (56).

The interrogative element is the head of this phrase; the string voor (een) N forms a PP which is base-adjoined to DP. The optional article een occupies the lower D-position and takes an NP-complement. It is assumed that the DP wat is not an argument of some predicate; e.g., it is not assigned a theta role by the verb. 19 It is the entire wat voor-phrase which is the argument of the verb. It is further proposed that the PP headed by voor behaves as predicative phrase with regard to wat. Support for the predicative status of the PP headed by voor is given by the following examples, where voor also shows up in predicative contexts.

(57)
a. Ik schold hem uit [voor (een) bedrieger].
I called him Prt for (an) impostor
‘I called him an impostor.’
b. Ik hield het [voor waar].
I held it for true
‘I took it to be true.’

Adopting a Barriers-type framework, Corver accounts for the possibility of subextracting wat in the following way. In (58) wat has been reordered out of a direct object noun phrase. Neither the Subjacency Condition nor the ECP is violated since the fronted wat can reach [Spec, CP] without crossing any barrier (i.e., a maximal projection that is not L-marked). The direct object-DP itself is L-marked (i.e., assigned a theta role by a lexical category) and therefore does not constitute a barrier for extraction. The potential barrierhood of VP can be voided via adjunction to it, and IP is not a barrier by stipulation. Schematically (note that the finite verb has been moved to C):
(58) [CP wati [C′ heb [IP je [VP t′i [VP [DP ti voor boek] gekocht]]]]]

Summarizing, Corver's analysis crucially assumes that the wat voor N-construction has a different phrasal structure than those nominal constructions (e.g., welke auto, ‘which car’) that do not feature subextraction. The former involves an adjunction configuration: a predicative PP is base-adjoined to the DP wat. In a nominal construction like welke auto, the wh-determiner welke heads the DP-projection and takes the NP auto as its complement: [DP [D′ welke [NP auto]]]. The D-head cannot be extracted from within the containing DP; see Corver's analysis of the left-branch effect in section 3.3. 20

subsection.heading: 4.2.4 The wat voor N-construction as a predicate displacement construction
subsection.p: The analyses presented thus far assume that the wh-element wat is base-generated as a left peripheral element within the containing noun phrase. Contrary to those analyses, Bennis et al. (1998) claim that the wh-element wat is in a derived position. They assume that wat originates as a DP-internal nominal predicate which is moved to the left periphery of the extended nominal projection (i.e., [Spec, DP]). 21 Obviously, this wh-movement process is similar to wh-movement within the clausal domain. According to this analysis, a noun phrase like wat voor boeken ‘what for books’ has the underlying structure in (59a). In this structure, the noun phrase contains a Small Clause structure (XP), which configurationally defines the predication relationship between boeken and wat. After predicate displacement has applied to the wh-word, wat ends up in [Spec, DP], which is the leftmost position within the nominal domain. This derived structure is given in (59b). 22

(59)
a. [DP [D′ voor[+wh] [XP boeken [X′ X wat]]]]
b. [DP wati [D′ voor[+wh] [XP boeken [X′ X ti]]]]

As depicted in (59), voor is taken to be a [+WH] operator head, i.e., a prepositional head with interrogative force. Evidence for this analysis comes from the fact that many southern varieties of Dutch and substandard Dutch in fact use voor as the infinitival complementizer in constructions that feature operator (OP) movement to [Spec, CP].

(60)
een boek [OPi
voor
[IP ti in te kijken]] Dutch
a book OP for – into to look
‘a book to look into’

(61)
Dit is een man [OPi voor
[IP PRO ti in het oog te houden]].
this is a man OP for PRO – in the eye to keep
‘That is a man to keep an eye on.’

The subextraction phenomenon is not dicussed by Bennis et al., though it is quite clear that the subextraction possibility should be related to the fact that the fronted wat occupies the highest A′-position within the extended nominal projection. Analogous to subextraction from the clausal domain via [Spec, CP], elements leave the noun phrase via [Spec, DP]. On the assumption that the specifier position of functional projections (like IP, CP, and DP) is accessible to an external proper governor, say, V, (cf. section 3.3) the extractability of wat is compatible with the ECP-constraint. Notice also that subextraction is compatible with Kennedy and Merchant's theory on subextraction (cf. section 3.4). They argued that subextraction from within a noun phrase (i.e., DP) is blocked if after subextraction has applied a nominal configuration is created with a feature specification on D for which no lexical item with a matching feature constellation can be found in the lexicon. Since the prepositional determiner voor carries the [+wh]-feature, subextraction of the wh-element wat from within DP does not yield an uninterpretable phonological representation.

subsection.heading: 4.3 A subject–object asymmetry
subsection.p: As first observed in Den Besten (1981), the wat voor-noun phrase can be split (by subextraction of wat) if it occupies the direct object position, but not when it is in the subject position of the clause, i.e., [Spec, IP] (see also Hoekstra 1984b; Koster 1987). Sentence (62) exemplifies subextraction of wat from a direct object noun phrase. The examples in (63) show that subextraction is not permitted when the wat voor-phrase is in [Spec, IP].

(62)
a. Wat heb je [– voor boeken] gelezen? Dutch
what have you – for books read
‘What kind of books have you read?’
b. Wat denk je dat Jan [– voor boeken] heeft gekocht?
what think you that John – for books has bought
‘What kind of books do you think John bought?’

(63)
a. *Wat
hebben [– voor mensen] gisteren hun huis verkocht?
what have – for people yesterday their house sold
‘What kind of people sold their house yesterday?’
b. *Wat
denk je dat [– voor mensen] hun huis hebben verkocht?
what think you that – for people their house have sold
‘What kind of people do you think have sold their house?’

Den Besten explains this subject–object asymmetry in terms of the Empty Category Principle (ECP). In (62), the trace left behind after subextraction of wat is properly governed by the verb which takes the noun phrase as its complement. The verb is able to govern the specifier position of the direct object noun phrase. For subjects, however, there is no proper governor, which explains the ungrammaticality of the examples in (63). Interestingly, a similar contrast can be observed in examples like (64) and (65).

(64)
a. Wat
werd hem gisteren [– voor iets] aangeboden?
what was him yesterday – for something offered
‘What kind of thing was offered to him yesterday?’
b. Wat
zijn hem toen [– voor rampen] overkomen?
what are him then – for disasters happened-to
‘What kind of disasters happened to him?’

(65)
a. *Wat
werd [– voor iets] hem gisteren aangeboden?
what was – for something him yesterday offered
‘What kind of thing was offered to him yesterday?’
b. *Wat
zijn [– voor rampen] hem toen overkomen?
what are – for disasters him then happened-to
‘What kind of disasters happened to him?’

If the contrast between (64) and (65) is to be explained in terms of ECP, it should be concluded that the grammatical subject wat voor iets/wat voor rampen (i.e., the noun phrase that agrees with the finite verb) occupies the (VP-internal) direct object position. Only in this position is the (specifier position of the) noun phrase properly governed by the verb. In (64a) it is a passive verb which acts as a proper governor; in (64b) an ergative verb properly governs the trace. In the ill-formed examples in (65) the grammatical subject is in the structural subject position, i.e., [Spec, IP], hence, no longer within the proper government domain of the verb. Consequently, subextraction is not permitted.

subsection.heading: 5 Subextraction in Slavic languages
subsection.p: As Ross (1986: 145ff.) himself already observed, left-branch-specifying or modifying elements can be removed from the nominal domain in a language like Russian: 23

(66)
a. Č′ju knigu
čitaješ –? Russian
whose book you-are reading-
‘Whose book are you reading?’
b. Č′ju čitaješ
[– knigu]?
whose you-are-reading – book
‘Whose book are you reading?’

Given the well-formedness of the subextraction in (66), Ross concludes that the LBC is not operative in Russian. The question, of course, arises whether this difference in subextraction behavior can be reduced to some grammatical property on which languages can vary. As was already hinted at by Ross, languages violating the LBC are characterized by a rich morphology. One might therefore want to propose that discontinuous patterns are possible as long as the dependency between the extracted specifier (e.g., in (66)) and the remote head (knigu) is morphologically recoverable. This is the approach taken by Horn (1974, 1978, 1983). He proposes a condition called the Noun Phrase Constraint (NPC), which excludes removal of any element from within the noun phrase. So this locality constraint rules out left- and right-branch extractions out of the English noun phrase:

(67)
a. *Which did you destroy [– book]?
b. *About whom did you destroy [a book –]?

Horn points out that in a language like Polish, subextraction of an agreeing element – which typically occurs on a left-branch – is permitted, while extraction of a non-agreeing constituent (e.g., a PP) is not:

(68)
a. Jakie pożyczyłeś [NP – ksi
żki] z biblioteki? Polish
which-Acc you-borrow – books-Acc from library
‘Which books did you borrow from the library?’
b. *O kim
on zniszczył [NP ksi
żk
–]?
about whom he destroyed book-Acc
‘He destroyed a book about whom?’

Adjectival forms like jaki are marked morphologically to agree with the head noun that they are related to in gender, number, and case. In contrast, PPs are not marked according to whether they occur in an NP. On the basis of the asymmetry in (68), Horn concludes that “the NPC is valid in Polish, but can be overridden just in case there are morphological markers present in the surface structure that can function to associate a constituent in Comp with an empty node elsewhere in the structure” (Horn 1983: 188).

In Corver (1990, 1992), a different approach is taken to the asymmetry between left-branch subextraction languages and non-subextraction languages. He relates the contrast to the configurational structure of the noun phrase, more specifically, the presence of the DP-layer within the extended nominal projection. That is, languages whose nominals project to DP do not permit subextraction of specifying or modifying elements. Languages whose nominal projections lack the DP-level (i.e., ‘bare’ NPs) permit subextraction from the nominal domain. 24 The impossibility of subextraction from DP in a language like English has been discussed in section 3.3. As regards the transparancy of bare NPs, consider the following structural environment, where α is the left-branch element targeted for movement:

In a Barriers framework, the extractability of left-branch specifiers (and modifiers) follows directly. The NP is L-marked by the verb and therefore does not constitute a barrier. Via intermediate adjunction to VP, the left-branch element can reach [Spec, CP] without violating Subjacency or the ECP. Schematically, (68a) has the following derived structure:

As pointed out by Corver (1990: 332), potential support for the claim that languages like Russian, Czech, and Polish lack a DP is the fact that they do not have articles corresponding to the or a in English (cf. also Zlatić (1997)). Clearly, articles are the canonical realizations of D. 25

(71)
Ptak patrzy na kota. Polish
bird looks at cat
‘The/a bird is looking at the/a cat.’

Corver further argues that potential candidates for the category D, like demonstratives, possessive pronouns, etc., should be analyzed as adjectives (see also Horn 1978, 1983). Being adjectives, they are part of the NP-projection. Evidence for their adjectival status comes from the fact that demonstratives and possessive pronouns have (declension) endings similar to normal adjectives.

As pointed out in Rappaport (2000), a bare NP-analysis for those languages that permit left-branch subextraction raises the question why subextraction of right-branch elements (e.g., PPs) is not permitted either (see also Horn 1974, 1978, 1983). If V takes a bare NP-complement containing a PP, this PP should be able to leave the NP, since the latter is L-marked by the verb and, therefore, not a barrier for extraction. As shown by the following examples, however, PPs cannot be removed from within the noun phrase (see also Horn); examples taken from Rappaport (2000):

(72)
a. *Z czym
postrzelili przed domem [chłopca –]? Polish
with what he-shot in-front-of house boy
‘With what did they shoot [a boy –] in front of the house?’
A: Ze skakank
with jump.rope
A: with a jump rope
b. *Od kogo
zniszczyłeś [list –]?
From whom you-destroyed letter –
‘From whom did you destroy [a letter –]?’
In English, right-branch adjunct-PPs cannot be removed either from within the noun phrase:

(73)
a. Peter kissed [a girl with red hair].
b. *With what did Peter kiss [a girl –]?

As Culicover and Rochemont (1992) noted, the ill-formedness of (73b) can be explained straightforwardly if one adopts the DP-hypothesis. The category NP, by which the adjunct-PP is dominated, forms a barrier for extraction. Rappaport argues that if right-branch PP-extractions are blocked in English by the presence of a DP, the Polish facts in (72) suggest that NPs are associated with a DP in this language as well. In other words, the ‘right-branch effect’ provides support for the presence of a DP-layer. 26

If languages permitting left-branch subextraction and those blocking it share the same nominal phrase structure (i.e., DP), the question arises how to account for the left-branch subextraction asymmetry. Following ideas proposed by Giorgi and Longobardi (1991) in their account of possessor-extraction phenomena, Rappaport argues that extraction of some element Y from within the nominal domain is possible if (i) [Spec, DP] is available as an intermediate landing site for Y, and (ii) the trace in [Spec, DP] can be lexically governed from outside (e.g., by V) (cf. section 3.3). As regards the first condition, it is stated that only those elements can move through [Spec, DP] that enter into a Spec–Head agreement relationship with D (this is under the assumption that D is the locus of phi-features and case). This implies that agreeing elements like attributive APs, possessive pronouns, and agreeing wh-elements can move through [Spec, DP] whereas non-agreeing modfiers like PPs cannot. The second condition states that the element in [Spec, DP] can leave this position only if the trace left behind can be lexically governed from outside, e.g., by V. In languages like Polish and Russian, V is able to govern into DP: [Spec, DP], that is, is accessible to government from outside. In a language like English (and other languages blocking left-branch subextraction), V is not able to govern the specifier of a DP-complement. Thus, on this analysis, the parametric distinction between Polish and Russian, on the one hand, and, say, English, lies in whether or not V has the ability to govern inside its DP-complement. 27

subsection.heading: 6 Conclusion
subsection.p: Displacement is a core property of natural language: satellite constituents of the verbal predicate can be reordered within the clausal domain, for example to [Spec, CP]. It was shown that it is sometimes not the entire satellite of the verbal predicate (say a direct object noun phrase) that moves to [Spec, CP], but a subpart of it (e.g., a left-branch wh-determiner). In those cases, subextraction applies to the satellite-XP: a left-branch element is moved out of the larger phrase that functions as an argument or a predicate within the clause. In certain languages, left-branch subextraction is blocked in general and is only found in certain construction types (e.g., subextraction of wat from within the wat voor N-construction). In other languages (e.g., Russian, Polish) subextraction of left-branch elements applies much more freely. The central questions that were addressed in this study were: (a) what grammatical property accounts for the inaccessibility of left-branch elements in those languages that generally block left-branch subextraction? (b) why are certain left-branch elements (e.g., wat in the wat voor N-construction) available for subextraction in those languages that generally do not allow subextraction? (c) what grammatical property explains the rather free accessibility of left-branch elements in such languages as Polish and Russian?

subsection.heading: NOTES

p.span: 1 Left-branch subextraction is permitted from the prepositional domain (cf. Emonds 1985; Corver 1990):

subsection.p:
(i)
a. How far did he go [– into the woods]?
b. How many meters did he raise his head [– above the water]?

p.span: 2 Right-branch modifiers typically cannot be removed either from within the nominal domain (cf. Bach and Horn 1976):

subsection.p:
(i)
a. *With how many wheels did John see [a car –]?
b. *From which shelf did Susan read [a book –]?
This chapter focusses on left-branch subextractions; see section 5 for a brief discussion on right branch subextractions.

p.span: 3 The impossibility of removing an NP from a larger, containing, NP is also captured by Chomsky's (1964a) A-over-A principle. This condition asserts that if a phrase X of category A (say, NP) is embedded within a larger phrase ZXW which is also of category A (say, NP), then no rule applying to category A applies to X (but only to ZXW); see also section 3.2.1.

4 Ross (1986: 127 ff.) does not discuss instances of determiner extractions, e.g., Which did he buy [– car]? Obviously, these cases of subextraction fall under the LBC, assuming that determiners are nominal (i.e., NPs).

5 Ross claims that the grammar of each language is provided with what he calls a conditions box, in which all language-particular constraints (e.g., the LBC) are stated once for the whole language. By a universal convention of interpretation, all conditions in the conditions box will be understood to be conditions on the operation of every rule in the grammar (topicalization, relative clause formation, question formation, etc.).

6 The idea that the periphery of a phrase is accessible to movement operations is also proposed in Chomsky (2000, 2001 b). He formulates his Phase Impenetrability Condition (PIC), which states that the domain of a head H is not accessible to operations outside HP, but only H and its edge. The edge is defined as the residue outside of H-bar, i.e., SPECs or elements adjoined to HP. Direct extraction of an element from the complement position of H to a position external to HP is not allowed. Extraction from HP must always proceed via the edge of HP.

7 Van Riemsdijk notes that the Head Constraint can be interpreted in terms of the c-command relation: an element cannot be extracted out of a maximal projection if it is within the c-command domain of the head of that maximal projection.
8 Pied-piping of the entire PP is also possible; e.g., Daarop heeft Jan gerekend and Waarop heeft Jan gerekend?

9 Another locality constraint that captures the Left Branch effect is Horn's (1974, 1978, 1983) Noun Phrase Constraint (see also Bach and Horn 1976). According to this condition, no element can be removed from within NP. See also section 5.
10 Chomsky's (1973) n. 10 suggests that he does not assume that the Left Branch effect reduces to a locality constraint like Subjacency (see section 3.1. for discussion).
11 As Giorgi and Longobardi point out, their Uniqueness Constraint on Government can be subsumed under the Minimality condition (Chomsky 1986a).

12 The question arises why English allows such strings as how big a car. If these are derived by movement of the AP to [Spec, DP], one would expect an ECP-violation. Corver (1990: 320) tentatively proposes that such strings as how big a car are not derived by syntactic movement of how big to [Spec, DP] but rather by a PF-process that lowers the ‘indefinite article’ to a position in between the attributive AP (which is NP-internal) and the noun. See Kennedy and Merchant (2000), though, for an analysis in which the DegP moves to [Spec, DP] in syntax.

13 Certain exclamative constructions in Dutch also display a split noun phrase. As shown in (ia), the entire exclamative noun phrase can be fronted. (ib) exemplifies the split pattern, which arguably involves subextraction of the wh-element wat.

subsection.p:
(i)
a. Wat een boeken heeft Jan – gekocht!
what a books has John – bought
‘The books John bought!’
b. Wat heeft Jan een boeken gekocht!

In Corver (1990) it is argued, though, that the split construction in (ib) does not involve subextraction from within the noun phrase; he points out that the element wat can be ‘removed’ from a noun phrase that is contained within an island (e.g., a PP-island; cf. (ii)).

(ii)
a. Wat is Jan [PP met [een leuke vrouw] getrouwd!
what is John with a nice woman married
‘John is married to such a nice woman!’
b. [PP Met [wat een leuke vrouw]] is Jan getrouwd!
Note that a wat voor N-noun phrase does not permit subextraction from such an island context (cf. (iiia)); pied-piping of the PP is required, as in (iiib).

(iii)
a. *Wat is Jan [PP met [– voor een vrouw]] getrouwd?
what is John with – for a woman married
‘What kind of woman is John married to?’
b. Met wat voor een vrouw is Jan getrouwd?
The phenomenon of subextraction from exclamative noun phrases has also been studied for Romance languages. See, for example, Gérard (1980), Milner (1978b), Obenauer (1976), and Radford (1982).

p.span: 14 The indefinite article een is optional in the Dutch wat voor N-construction. A remarkable property of this indefinite article in Dutch is its cooccurrence with a plural N: wat voor een boeken (‘what kind of books’). In Bennis et al. (1998), it is claimed that this (spurious) indefinite article does not belong to the following noun (and nor to the preceding wh-element). They argue that een is the head of a DP-internal Small Clause, i.e., X, in (59).
15 The wat voor N-construction has also been examined for other Germanic languages. See, e.g., Lie (1982) for Norwegian, Borjärs (1992) for Swedish, Den Besten (1981), and Beermann (1997) for German.
16 On the basis of the Swedish hva for N-construction, Lie (1982) proposes that S′ rather than S is the bounding node for Subjacency in Swedish.

17 The observation that the string voor N may undergo PP Extraposition was made in Bennis (1983). There is vacillation about the well-formedness of such split patterns involving PP-extraposition (see Den Besten 1985).
18 Den Besten takes NP and S as bounding nodes for Dutch.

19 Evidence for the nonargument-status of wat comes from a number of phenomena: (a) movement of wat across a wh-island yields a strong (i.e., ECP) violation (cf. (i)); (b) wat cannot be moved across negation (i.e., sensitivity to the negative island effect; cf. (ii)); (c) the trace of wat cannot license a parasitic gap (pg) (cf. (iii)). See Corver (1990, 1991b), Honcoop (1998) for discussion.

subsection.p:
(i)
*Wat vraag jij je af [wanneer Jan [– voor boeken] gekocht heeft]?
what wonder you Refl Prt when John – for books bought has

(ii)
*Wat heeft Jan niet [– voor boeken] gelezen?
what has John not – for books read
‘What kind of books didn't John read?’

(iii)
Wat heeft Jan [zonder PRO [pg voor tijdschriften] te lezen [– voor boeken] weggegooid?
what has John without PRO pg for magazines to read – for books thrown away
Extraction of argumental wat does not display the above-mentioned effects.
(iv) ??Wat vraag jij je af [wanneer Jan – gekocht heeft]?
(v) Wat heeft Jan niet – gelezen?
(vi) Wat heeft Jan [zonder PRO pg te lezen] – weggegooid?

p.span: 20 Borjärs develops an analysis of the Swedish vad for N-construction in which vad is analyzed as the D-head and for N as the PP-complement of the wh-element. She points out that such an analysis leaves unaccounted for the subextraction contrast between a vad for N-construction and a nominal construction like vilken N (which N). She explores the possibility that vad is base-generated in [Spec, DP], a position which is accessible to movement.

21 See Postma (1994, 1995) and Bennis (1995) for a discussion of the meaning of wat. They both come to the conclusion that the meaning of wat is determined by the structural configuration in which it occurs. That is, if wat remains in its base position (e.g., complement to V), it gets an indefinite reading (cf. (i)), and if it occurs in the specifier position of an interrogative C, it gets an interrogative interpretation under Spec–Head agreement (cf. (ii)).

subsection.p:
(i)
Jan heeft wat gegeten.
John has what eaten
‘John has eaten something.’

(ii)
Wat heeft Jan – gegeten?
what has John eaten
‘What did John eat?’

Bennis et al. (1998) assume that the element wat in the wat voor N-construction gets its interrogative force by occupying the Spec position of an interrogative (prepositional) determiner, namely, voor.

p.span: 22 Bennis et al. (1998) argue that in wat voor N-constructions featuring the (spurious) indefinite article een, two types of predicate-movements take place. First, the nominal predicate wat undergoes Predicate Inversion (i.e., A-movement) to the Spec-position of some higher functional head F. This movement of the nominal predicate across the subject of the DP-internal Small Clause (boeken in (i)) can apply only if the indefinite article heading the SC has raised to the higher functional head F; this is so for reasons of locality (i.e., Equidistance, cf. Chomsky 1995c). The second step involves movement of wat from [Spec, FP] to the operator-position [Spec, DP]. Schematically:

subsection.p: (i) [DP wati [D′ voor [FP t′i [F′ Xj (= een) + F [XP boeken [X′ tj ti]]]]]]

p.span: 23 In Rappaport (2000) it is claimed that the Left Branch Condition is observed in Polish for extraction from Adjective (and Adverb) Phrases. He gives the following examples:

subsection.p:
(i)
a. *Jak Piotr jest [– m
dry]?
how Peter is – smart
‘How smart is Peter?’
b. Jak m
dry jest Piotr?

(ii)
a. Jak on [– ładnie] recytuje wiersze?
how he well recites poetry
‘How well does he recite poetry?’
b. Jak ładnie on – recytuje wiersze?
How well he – recites poetry
In Horn (1983), it is argued that sometimes left-branch subextraction from AP is possible. He gives the following examples from Polish:

(iii)
Bardzo czuł si
[– niepewnie].
very he-felt Refl – uncertainly
‘He felt very uncertain.’

(iv)
?Bardzo studenci w mojej grupie s
[– wysocy].
very students in my group are – tall
‘The students in my group are very tall.’

In Borsley (1981), finally, it is observed that the uninflected wh-degree word jak (‘how’) cannot be removed from within the adjectival phrase in Polish (see also Rappaport 2000). He argues that subextraction is possible, however, when jak is inflected (cf. (vi)). As shown by the b-examples, pied-piping of the entire AP always yields a well-formed sentence:

(v)
a. *Jak Jan jest przystojny?
how John is handsome
‘How handsome is John?’
b. Jak przystojny jest Jan?

(vi)
a. Jaki Jan jest przystojny?
b. Jaki przystojny jest Jan?

p.span: 24 For other studies in which a bare-NP analysis is defended, see, among others, Rozwadowska (1995a), Willim (1997, 2000), Zlátić (1997), Stjepanović (2000).
25 See also Uriagereka (1988) for the observation that left-branch extraction correlates with the ‘richness’ of D. The Left Branch Condition, he argues, holds for languages with D rich.
26 For further studies on the Slavic noun phrase, in which a DP-structure is adopted, see, e.g., Fowler and Franks (1994), Babyonyshev (1998), Engelhardt and Trugman (1998, 2000), Progovac (1998).
27 In the final part of his paper, Rappaport (2001) presents a minimalist account of the left-branch effects, making use of Chomsky's Phase Impenetrability Condition (Chomsky 1998, 1999). See note 6.
